content.html:
Ava started a Bear Blog question challenge this month and Kev adapted them to be a bit more generic. Several indieweb pals have posted their responses. I miss these kind of meta posts, so here are my responses:

1. Why did you start blogging in the first place?

I don’t remember the exact inspiration, but it was probably when I came across Blogger or maybe it was a Xanga blog. I had been tinkering with my GeoCities site since the late 90s, but that was more of a general collection of pages than a “weblog.”

In 1999, I decided to get this domain in part because I was coming around to the “gRegorLove” nickname that my friend Phil had given me. I thought it would be funny to set up a wife application (archived) on my own site. I also wanted to experiment with things like Blogger. I remember thinking it was so cool to be able to publish posts by FTP.

Sometime in 2000 I started posting more blog-type posts. It seemed so novel and was cool to be able to share text like that in my little corner of the web.

2. What platform are you using to manage your blog and why did you choose it?

I have been using the ProcessWire CMS/framework for almost ten years now. Before that I used Nucleus CMS for a long time. And before that I briefly experimented with B2evolution and Blogger.

I switched to ProcessWire because official development on Nucleus had stopped, unfortunately. I really enjoyed Nucleus’ extensibility and I made some of my first open source contributions there, but I wasn’t in a place to take on being one of the few remaining contributors.

I had used ProcessWire professionally for several sites and I really enjoyed its flexibility for building any type of site, not just a blog system that could be hacked into other types of things. ProcessWire is built entirely on custom fields and custom templates, so it allows a lot of creativity and not just a timeline of reverse chronological posts.

3. Have you blogged on other platforms before?

I posted on Xanga for quite a while. I think most of those posts still exist on my site, though. The phrase “Publish on your Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere” (POSSE) didn’t exist then, but I definitely had the desire to keep the original posts on my site and cross-post them.

4. How do you write your posts? For example, in a local editing tool, or in a panel/dashboard that’s part of your blog?

Half the time I will write in the ProcessWire editor (like now). The other half of the time I will use Sublime Text or Obsidian. I have used Writemonkey in the past because I enjoyed the ability to type in full-screen with no distractions. It has optional typewriter sound effects, too, which was fun. I think my use of that mostly dropped off because ProcessWire has a decent visual editor.

5. When do you feel most inspired to write?

Whenever I see that the last post was a month or two ago? ???? Though seriously, I updated my homepage to show the full content of the latest article for the first 45 days. After that, it changes to just the title + link under the “Other Recent Articles” heading. That can serve as a little visual nudge for me to write something if I notice that.

Inspirations vary. Sometimes I want to document everyday things for myself to look back on. Sometimes I want to put together various bits of information in one space and (hopefully) make it easier to digest, e.g. with some of my posts about health and safety. Sometimes I just want to vent.

6. Do you publish immediately after writing, or do you let it simmer a bit as a draft?

Most posts I am pretty casual about. I might let a draft sit overnight and re-read it to tweak some phrasing. My longer or more important (to me) posts will definitely be drafted and re-written over time, like “Four Years of Blank”.

7. What’s your favorite post on your blog?

Oof, this question is unfair. You saw that I’ve been posting for almost 25 years, right? ????I think I might have to stretch the rules on this one and give some favorites in entirely arbitrary categories.

  • Favorite look back/in-the-feels: “Ten Years On”
  • Favorite short fiction: “Drabble: A Paradox”
  • Favorite visual creative stuff: “Don’t Multitask with Fire”
  • Favorite weird: “Top Five Worst Ways to Refer to Human Hair”

8. Any future plans for your blog? Maybe a redesign, a move to another platform, or adding a new feature?

I have thought several times that I should bring back and modernize the wife application. That was some good silly fun.

I have been pretty pleased with the design I’ve had since 2011. It’s definitely the longest period I’ve gone without a full redesign. I have added a lot of different types of posts since then, so the navigation probably needs some updates. I have made updates to the homepage to try to highlight some of those, like photos and notes. I don’t think I want the homepage to strictly be a reverse chronological feed of everything, though. Short notes would drown out the blog posts, so I still want to promote the blog posts by “pinning” them or something.

One of my favorite things about the design is the picture of me in the footer. That was taken in Chicago at Lake Michigan quite a while ago. Now that I live in California, I have thought about getting an updated version of that shot, but at the beach instead. I need to ask Al about that.

Bonus round: tag/nudge some other people to fill this out

This is my little addition to the prompts. If you blog, I’d love to read your responses as well. If you don’t, maybe this is a good time to start!

I’d like to nudge: Sheryl, Isha, Rachelskirts, and Tyler.

content.html: @reillypascal On a somewhat unrelated topic, I find it fun sometimes to deliberately introduce massive fragmentation on a FAT or FAT32 volume. Create an empty volume, mount it, fill the volume up with thousands of tiny files (I have a Python script that does a nice job of this), delete a subset of them, see how much space you have free, copy one or more audio files to fill the free space, delete more tiny files, fill the space up with audio files, etc. Then when you're done, dismount the volume and open the image in an audio editor. It helps if the filler audio files you're using have the same parameters as how you open the raw volume image. What you'll find, after the FATs and such, is disorganized chaos, as the operating system has no choice but to put random bits and pieces of the audio files wherever it can. Sometimes it doesn't work out that way, but sometimes it does, and when it does, it's a beautiful, chaotic mess.

It helps if the filler audio files you're using have the same parameters as how you open the raw volume image. What you'll find, after the FATs and such, is disorganized chaos, as the operating system has no choice but to put random bits and pieces of the audio files wherever it can. Sometimes it doesn't work out that way, but sometimes it does, and when it does, it's a beautiful, chaotic mess.

content.html: @reillypascal And oh yeah, by audio files, I mean wavs, not MP3s or other compressed files, as those will just sound like white noise.

content.html: @reillypascal Another sometimes interesting source of noise is Linux or other server logs, or other types of event logs. The key here is to find something with enough repetitiveness to give it a good base, yet enough variability so it doesn't all sound the same. I just noisified /var/log/mail.log on a server I run, which sounded mostly the same, white noise type noise with bursts of other noise, but it was always a bit different due to the random nature of the data E.G. Emails going in and out, random hackers trying to attack the mail server and their attempts being logged, etc. but I could definitely tell when a mailing I sent out to around 370 people happened mid-week.

content.html: @reillypascal If you have a drive, back it up using any utility that produces raw images. On Linux, DD will do the trick quite nicely, just make sure you get the device names correct as it provides absolutely no confirmation and will happily overwrite a perfectly good disk with random garbage if you tell it to do so. It can also write to files, so something like dd if=/dev/sda1 of=myfile.dat bs=1M would work. Also if you have a way to mount such images, you can use Mkdosfs from Dosfstools I think it's called to create such a filesystem, mount it, and mess around with that volume.
content.text: @reillypascal If you have a drive, back it up using any utility that produces raw images. On Linux, DD will do the trick quite nicely, just make sure you get the device names correct as it provides absolutely no confirmation and will happily overwrite a perfectly good disk with random garbage if you tell it to do so. It can also write to files, so something like dd if=/dev/sda1 of=myfile.dat bs=1M would work. Also if you have a way to mount such images, you can use Mkdosfs from Dosfstools I think it's called to create such a filesystem, mount it, and mess around with that volume.

content.html: @reillypascal Also if you have access to an image of a FAT32 filesystem which has been well used, files added, deleted, and in general shows signs of heavy use, try that. About the first thing you'll hear is a bunch of static with some interesting noises, that gets louder and softer, and also has more and less treble over time. There will be two identical segments of this, and these are the file allocation tables. Then you'll hear data from whatever files were on the volume, with occasional chirps of around 2756.5 Hz. These are the directories on the disk.

content.html: @reillypascal What I'd tend to say is, the more complicated the MIDI, the better. If it's just someone playing the piano or something like that, it probably won't be that interesting, but if there are intricate patterns and complicated arrangements repeated in the music, it can lead to some interesting noises. I have a MIDI of Rush E that makes some cool noises, for example.

content.html:
I'm making some more databending sounds today, and this one sounds surprisingly like a damped music box!

It reminds me of the custom music box machines from Clara Iannotta's "The People Here Go Mad. They Blame The Wind" (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hynpA1YmY9o). I believe she has some wood boxes with 12 music boxes, motors to run them, and adjustable dampers.

content.html:
Sara and Reilly and Jo and now Tracy did them. I enjoyed these questions, and reading those and other fellow bloggers’ answers. They all have things in common, and all have things that are very specifically them. My turn.

1. Why did you make the blog in the first place?

In the late 90s I became convinced everyone would have a website. I had one! My website opened up so many incredible opportunities professionally and personally. Who wouldn’t want that? Blogs were a way to share–writing, links, photos–regularly.

I was good with HTML, and was good with making images. Websites were (and are) great.

2. Why did you choose [the blogging software/platform/tool you use]?

When I learned that Blogger.com had a way to publish a blog to a website via FTP.

That was February of 2001. I could have my site, and include the blog as an Apache server side include.

Here’s how that looked in November 2001.

3. Have you blogged on other platforms before?

I changed to WordPress in 2004, after blogging on b2 on San Diego Blog. I also set up internal blogs using Movable Type to track work internally for an employer.

And others. AOL Journals. LiveJournal. Tumblr. GreyMatter. TextPattern. And of course Blogger. And Drupal. And others I can’t remember off the top of my head.

tl;dr: YES.

4. Do you write your posts directly in the editor or in another software?

This post I’m writing in a browser on my laptop. Sometimes they’ll start as an email I send to myself then cut and paste into the site later. Some start as a text file written in BBEdit. I’ve experimented with some other microblogging tools, and the WordPress app. And some other tools with export or API linkage to WordPress but none of them ever stuck.

5. When do you feel most inspired to write?

When something angers me. Or amazes me. Or makes me feel hope. It’s probably big emotion that’s the impetus, usually.

It’s irritating when I get inspired and the weather is great and the surf looks good but I need to get some writing down.

But I’m happy and thankful when inspiration strikes.

6. Do you publish immediately after writing or do you let it simmer a bit as a draft?

I don’t have the discipline–usually–to simmer.

After pushing “Publish” on a long piece I will often find things I want to fix, whether that’s spelling or grammar or phrasing.

It’s the times when I take my time that the posts turn out stronger.

7. Your favorite post on your blog?

I gave this a lot of thought.

Mr. Roth Caricature, 1987. It’s a caricature of my high school physics professor and a short recollection. It’s not a great post, but it’s honest, and respectful. Every few years, someone who had him as a teacher will leave a comment remembering the man. Or send me an email. It makes me so glad to have a website that’s findable and searchable and open to the world. My website connects me to the wider world and I have tangible proof that I’ve contributed something of value. That’s the best of the web to me: our collective memory.

My late Mom’s favorite post was Shoe Photoshop. I got an email the day she read it. She said she’d printed it out and was so proud I had a way with words. She was an enthusiastic booster of my work, and that’s a good memory. And that’s the piece I chose to read at L.A. Bloggers Live back in 2007.

8. Any future plans for your blog? Maybe a redesign, changing the tag system, etc.?

I’m always tinkering. Because of my indieweb ethos anything I can do to get social media, checkins, music scrobbles, whatever onto my site is always the plan. But also, probably new headers and color schemes.

Thanks for reading. This was fun.

content.html:
I don't believe I was tagged by anyone but wanted to join in as it seemed like a fun writing challenge. A different version of this lives in my colophon but this is possibly a more readable and easier to understand version.

1. Why did you make the blog in the first place?

I'm not sure if I consider my site a blog. I wrote the first versions of this website in 2015 and it just used to be a landing page with links to other sites and the rare blog post. Sometime later I learned more about the IndieWeb and I decided that instead of posting random thoughts, movie watches, book reads, and photos elsewhere I would use my site as the main place where I post things and here we are.

2. Why did you choose [the blogging software/platform/tool you use]?

Everything was originally handwritten HTML but this involved a lot of copying and pasting code which was OK when there were only 5 pages. A static site generator made sense to me since I wanted to be able to build and upload to a server with minimal setup on that side. After trying out a few, I stuck with this fairly new project at the time called Eleventy and haven't looked back.

I've also been on and off selfhosting and using Netlify to publish my site. Lastly, I wrote a serverless micropub endpoint which would be able to add posts to my site by using a Micropub Client and, even though it hasn't been really updated in a few years, I'm happy to say it's still working well for my setup.

3. Have you blogged on other platforms before?

I've posted online in several places including forums, Blogger, MySpace, Tumblr, Medium, dev.to and they all worked for me well at the time. I have also tried out other blogging platforms for work but never have really used them for myself.

4. Do you write your posts directly in the editor or in another software?

Most of the stuff that I post on my site I write directly in my micropub client: spakles. There are a few situations where if it's an article with a little more complex formatting and styling, I load up my local dev environment and write the post in my text editor.

5. When do you feel most inspired to write?

Inspiration usually comes right after reading something from other blogs I follow.

6. Do you publish immediately after writing or do you let it simmer a bit as a draft?

I find myself writing and never posting more often than actually posting. I think writing is good practice for me and it helps me build confidence for when I actually hit publish. I currently have eight posts in drafts and some may stay there forever while others my eventually get posted.

7. Your favorite post on your blog?

I really liked writing my Films To Be Buried With post as that is a podcast I really enjoy and I already spent my time while listening to it thinking about my answers. In terms of style or fun features, I liked writing My Favorite Mugs as I got to play around with SVGs and interactive images.

8. Any future plans for your blog?

I sometimes wish I had time to redesign things but the truth is I'm quite happy with how things look and I also don't have a better idea. In terms of things you may not see but I've been planning to work on for a while is rewritting my Micropub Endpoint as I want that to be a little easier to use for others than the current way it's setup. I do sometimes add things to my /TODO which aren't necessarily tasks as much as they are ideas for someday.

I won't be tagging anyone but if you're reading this, I definitely want to read your post. Here's some of the posts I read that inspired me to write this one:

  • https://reillyspitzfaden.com/posts/2025/01/blog-tag-game/
  • https://sarajaksa.eu/2025/01/blog-questions-challenge/
  • https://dead.garden/blog/blog-questions.html
  • https://tracydurnell.com/2025/01/15/blog-questions-challenge/
  • https://jlelse.blog/posts/blog-questions-challenge

content.html:
Reilly shared this blog tag game and Dom tagged me so I’ll join in!

1. Why did you make this blog in the first place?

No one else’s website looked like it, but it was too much of a pain to update and the only way to use the nav on mobile was zooming in and out because the leaves were an image map so also it wasn’t accessible

My domain had sat stagnant as a hand-coded HTML site for many years as I had it in my head that I needed to design websites from scratch, and I was burned out on web design. It became one of those lingering shoulds in the back of my mind, haunting me, but I felt obligated to have a portfolio website. Then Google started to nag and downrank me because my site wasn’t mobile friendly/ responsive, so it had just become this massive drag ????

Then I encountered the idea of digital gardens and was enchanted. I wanted a blog where I didn’t feel constrained by topics — my previous blog Cascadia Inspired was quite thematic, to the point I didn’t even post pictures from trips I’d taken to the Southwest because it was PNW-focused — and where I felt less self-imposed pressure about the quality of what I posted. I decided I wasn’t going to be freelancing any time soon (famous last words lol) so I could do without a portfolio site. Almost as soon as I took down the portfolio site and set up the new blog format, I adored it.

2. Why did you choose WordPress?

I researched some options for setting up a digital garden and couldn’t figure out why I needed anything special when I could use WordPress with self-pingbacks. (Since then I’ve recognized some gaps, but I’m still fine with it for now, especially since the site’s become more commonplace book than garden.)

3. Have you blogged on other platforms before?

In college I blogged on Blogger. I put together a little timeline of my past blogs ????

4. How do you write your posts?

I write directly in the editor in browser, and it is a truly egregiously bad practice that I’m hoping to improve this year ???? I tested out blogging in Scrivener last year, but it felt like overkill.

Recently I’ve been doing a bit of editing in Google Docs and Word; the challenge is formatting. I collect a bunch of links and notes in a draft post, often add in some loose headers for structure, then copy and paste into the word processor. Annoyingly, block quotes and headings get lost when pasted back into WordPress. I only just realized last week that if I start from text view, then all the code gets brought into the word processor — it looks ugly and can be hard to parse while I’m working in it, but at least it preserves the formatting ????‍♀️ This isn’t ideal but probably better than writing only in-browser? TBD.

I do incorporate previewing my writing often while editing in browser, and the word processor doesn’t allow that. (When previewing, I check for things like paragraphs that are too long or blocks of text that could benefit from more headings or bolded text for skimmability; I tend to write long so I want people to be able to figure out if they’re interested easily.)

5. When do you feel most inspired to write?

I’m inspired to blog all the time — so many interesting things happening online and in the world! — to the point I’m trying to shift away from leaning so much on inspiration. I still want to participate in the conversational web, but also want to be more intentional in what I spend time thinking about — to have a more balanced mix of posts in reaction versus self-prompted.

6. Do you publish immediately or let it simmer a bit?

I like to post anything short right away, but longer posts I’ll let sit. Sometimes I’ll write a post and run out of time to add one or two more paragraphs I think it needs, then I forget to come back for so long it doesn’t feel worthwhile to post anymore. Lately I’ve been working on cleaning up my drafts folder and stealing bits and pieces from posts that are never going up on their own.

7. Your favorite post on your blog?

One favorite??? ???? I’m feeling super proud of my new mindset of more series, but I don’t know if that’s because I just wrote them ????

Finding Enough Together is a post I link back to often. This is the type of post I think has the most value to write, and probably to read; it documents how my thinking has been shifting, tackles a Big Problem, and synthesizes a lot of reading. Tied up in that, for this particular post I’m really happy about the direction I’m moving in and feel good about the changes I’m making.

I’m proudest of writing posts like this, though I always feel wary about coming across like I’ve figured everything out and have my act together, which I most certainly do not ???? At the same time, I think it’s useful — in general, but especially for me personally — to make assertions with some level of confidence; even within complexity and nuance we can commit to a line of thought.

8. Any future plans for your blog?

I’ve been thinking about portability and longevity since all the ruckus with WordPress last year. The organization has been headed away from my preferred blogging direction for many years, and basically I’m gone the instant the classic editor is no longer supported. But, I also currently rely on the Post Kinds plugin to store additional data about posts if they are responding to or quoting from another website — and I’m not sure how portable those data are. I’m not planning to move anywhere yet, but I know WordPress is all in on the block editor, so it’s only a matter of time before I’ll be forced to switch… so it’s better for me to start thinking about now.

A more fun thing I’m intrigued by but don’t really know how to do is featuring all the books included in a blog post, and having a nice display for all the posts related to a book, like on Mandy Brown’s website.

Something else I’ve been pondering is how to make more personalized pages, like Anh does for posts sometimes, or Robin Rendle’s stories (kind of mini zines). I recently stumbled across some cool illustrated essays on Jay Perry’s site, and Joe just set up a digital zine with Leoh Blooms. I’d also like to figure out a less linear / more organic design for my garden section.

I’ve been thinking about portability and longevity since all the ruckus with WordPress last year. The organization has been headed away from my preferred blogging direction for many years, and basically I’m gone the instant the classic editor is no longer supported. But, I also currently rely on the Post Kinds plugin to store additional data about posts if they are responding to or quoting from another website — and I’m not sure how portable those data are. I’m not planning to move anywhere yet, but I know WordPress is all in on the block editor, so it’s only a matter of time before I’ll be forced to switch… so it’s better for me to start thinking about now.
A more fun thing I’m intrigued by but don’t really know how to do is featuring all the books included in a blog post, and having a nice display for all the posts related to a book, like on Mandy Brown’s website.
Something else I’ve been pondering is how to make more personalized pages, like Anh does for posts sometimes, or Robin Rendle’s stories (kind of mini zines). I recently stumbled across some cool illustrated essays on Jay Perry’s site, and Joe just set up a digital zine with Leoh Blooms. I’d also like to figure out a less linear / more organic design for my garden section.

content.html:
I’ve been trying to hang out and read in the rocking chair more but that window lets the cold in — thought my lazy lap blanket shoveoff looked artful ????

Win of the week: took the whole week off work

Looking forward to: finishing the blog posts I’m working on ????

Stuff I did:

  • I’m cranking away on a multi-post blog series ???? I was hoping to post the intro this week, but I realized I need to get the posts into a little bit better shape to make sure I’m setting them up well
  • I also worked on my year-end reading and listening posts, but I’m waiting in case I read something incredible in the next four days ????
  • Updated my 2024 listening page, which I let slide in summer — I didn’t fill in all monthly info but did list out track purchases and statistics — I’ll probably bail on making a 2025 listening page ????‍♀️
  • Did an intense music library clean up, removing some artists wholesale, sorting compilations out by artist and only keeping the good tracks
  • Reviewed another blog post draft, and got another request that I’ve booked for January while I take care of the rest I committed to in December ???? Reilly posted their article I looked at, it turned out awesome ????
  • Baked sourdough coffee cake for solstice brunch (bake notes) — was originally planning to make sourdough apple coffee cake with leftover sliced apples from last week but I had A Doubt about them — alas, it seems even this had enough butter to make my stomach mad ???? Darn missing gallbladder!
  • Made pumpkin pancakes with pecans and whipped cream ???? (Importantly, this did not anger my stomach ????)
  • Set up our new dinner table chairs and they look great! ???? The cats LOVE them ????
  • Met my friend for a midday walk at the state park twice
  • One virtual appointment

Dinners:

  • “Seattle dogs” with cream cheese and grilled onions (I use a Field Roast sausage)
  • Boxed tomato soup + cheese toasties
  • Mexican takeout — everyone else had the same idea, their parking lot was slammed ????
  • “Marry Me Chickpeas” + baked potato — the chickpeas smelled kinda weird (maybe because I subbed coconut milk and Swiss chard?) but tasted fine with the potatoes — took way longer than it said to prep
  • Baked feta pasta
  • King Arthur sourdough biscuits (too salty, otherwise good) + Ivar’s smoked salmon chowder

Reading:

  • Read Radium Girls by Cy. and Tin to Table by Anna Hezel
  • Re-read Choosing Theo by Victoria Aveline
  • Continued reading Come Together by Emily Nagoski and Capitalist Realism by Mark Fisher
  • Started reading The Midcentury Kitchen by Sarah Archer and Her Alien Mates by Susan Hayes
  • Received Octavia Butler’s A Few Rules for Predicting the Future
  • Ordered Oral Tradition and the Internet by John Foley

Words I looked up / concepts I learned:

Albums:

Website notes:

My post In praise of the hundred page idea was shared on Hacker News, and I received several nice emails from folks! Thanks for being great, Internet peeps ????

Welcome to anyone who stuck around — I post weeknotes every Friday evening, all other posts are ad hoc ???? I have a separate RSS feed for my book reviews — mostly fiction, graphic novels and art books.

Nature notes:

The weather was good so I threw my camas bulbs in the ground. They probably won’t take since they’re two months late, but I figured they have some marginal chance in the ground versus none in the box in my house. The allium bulbs had gone moldy and the crocuses are definitely a wash, but camas blooms in May, so possibly ????‍♀️

I already forgot I planted another Oregon grape in the backyard… it’s flowering up a storm for such a wee plant! I hope the flowers last till the bumblebees come out ????

children.name: What is the impact of online writing?

content.html:
What’s special about online writing?

Blog posts, microblog posts, email newsletters, social media posts, comments — these are self-published pieces of writing by regular people, most of whom are not getting paid to write. Most people would have had limited access to this type of writing fifty years ago, when self-published writing was zines and, like, church newsletters. Before the internet made self-publishing easy, most people’s exposure to writing by other regular people would have been letters from people they knew and letters to the editor.

It turns out it is extremely compelling to read thoughts by other regular people, even strangers. To hear from people who live in other parts of the world. To learn from people’s varied experiences. To connect with others who share our interests.

As people turn away from traditional media sources and shift their trust to individuals*, clearly online media matters to our offline lives. It matters what people are saying online, how they’re saying it, and why it resonates with us. It matters who is posting online.

(*Much of this transition is also a shift from text to audio and video — more on why that’s important later ????)

It’s also empowering for regular people to be able to publish where anyone might be able to read our words: the open web. Gatekeepers like editorial boards and publishers can no longer stop those they disagree with from reaching an audience. For most time periods, archaeologists and historians can only *dream* of having access to writing by regular people, when only the words of the wealthy were recorded, to understand cultures of the past.

But of course, simply being able to publish is not enough. We need to be read — and to be read, we need to be found.

Online writing is under threat from all sides

Audiences are switching to listening to audio (podcasts) and watching video (YouTube, TikTok) instead of reading text. More and more of online text is generated by LLMs; the human-authored content we’re looking for is getting harder and harder to find in the mountain range of AI slop and enshittified online versions of legacy media — an overgrown media ecosystem that’s evolved through insidious incentives and pressures. Even some human writers are getting sloppy and leaning on generative AI for research.

Over the past several years, online search has degraded through shifts in the algorithm, more and harder-to-identify sponsored posts, and an explosion of features that mean readers don’t need to click through to pages, including generative AI summaries. Outbound links are suppressed on social platforms; traffic to traditional news media online — and independent writers — has collapsed. Without traffic, independent commercial sites gain no ad or referral revenue and independent writers gain no attention.

At the same time, corporations and organizations keep showing they see no value in maintaining archives that are only available online. I’ve seen article after article pointing out the collapse of the old web. The Internet Archive is under attack. Link rot degrades the writing that remains — so what exactly is it that we are losing?

What’s the best of online writing?

The wrong question

At first, I tried to compile a “canon” of classic Internet writing, specific posts that originated cultural concepts. Not memes, but the kind of thing someone sends you a screencap of with the message “THIS” ???? A post that captures either a moment in culture or collective realization. An artifact you can point to that draws together the vibes of the moment. A perfect term or metaphor that’s adopted instantly. The references that pop up again, and again, and again…

But when I explained this idea to friends to crowdsource posts, I quickly discovered that barely anyone had encountered the posts I gave as examples*, and no one knew all of them.

*before you ask: The Spoon Theory blog post by Christine Miserandino, Alex Blechman’s torment nexus tweet, the nazi bar Twitter thread by Michael Tager, Frank Wilhoit’s comment on a blog post defining conservatism; I should have included the 1000 True Fans blog post by Kevin Kelly. These examples are a capsule of “my” Internet, the online culture vocabulary that I have found essential to my understanding of conversations in certain spaces.

Online writing follows the rules of oral culture

As I pondered why my internet canon idea was a flop, I’ve drawn three conclusions about online writing:

  1. most internet writing is part of oral culture; hypertext allows more conversational writing that invites readers into a network by directly linking to other writers while encouraging participation in the current Discourse
  2. because online writing is more relational than offline writing and hypertext means a single post need not stand alone, it is more often an online writer’s oeuvre rather than a single post that influences readers, and individual works are not necessarily intended to last; and sometimes an idea is within the community* and no one writer has synthesized it in one place
    *As Jay Springett writes, “The idea is fully expressed somewhere inside the network of links and discussions between people. Not anywhere in particular.” My example is the conversation the community has been having about connection between blogs, wherein I’ve collected my piece of the conversation starting here.
  3. because so much of how we read the Internet is rooted in relationships, and everyone has a different network, there is no one Internet canon — everyone has their own

Implications for online writing’s cultural and personal impact

It’s hard to pinpoint which particular piece of writing was the source of a revelation; often, no one piece is, but the chorus of voices together. It may not even come as a revelation, but a slow shifting. I couldn’t point to an individual #MeToo post that on its own was a turning point, but I will assert that the movement changed the way we talk and think about sexual violence. Even Cory Doctorow’s concept of enshittification emerged across several pieces.

Robert Poynton noticed that the valuable part of discussing books with others was not the ‘content’ but the conversation:

What seems obvious to me now is that the ‘content’ of what is presented is not the most important thing, it is the other people and what they make of what they see (or feel, or notice) through the lens of their own experience.

[…]

Contrary to what you might expect, it turns out that the books aren’t actually that important. Where the conversations gain power and traction is not in the immediate reaction to the texts themselves, but in the cumulative and iterative responses to the responses.

The heart of the conversation Poynton describes is how we write together online: our blog posts, our tweets, our newsletters — the places where we collectively process and mash up and pass along ideas — are what make the internet worth reading.

Sometimes bloggers think that nothing they write is valuable. Sometimes people never start to write because they think they have nothing worth saying. Sometimes people let their archives disappear or scrub them themselves (e.g. iirc the Nazi bar thread has been deleted). But that’s fear talking — because it is simply not true that online writing has no impact.

Artemis points out the common fear bloggers have of repeating ideas:

In the world of the digital, many of us have been tricked into thinking that something only needs to be said once. If someone has stated something, then stating it again is noise. Provides no purpose. Does not benefit anyone. The extension of this follows: I should not write something, on the off-chance that someone else whom I don’t even know about has already written it, perhaps better. The fear of being more incomplete than an imagined other-expert.

We want to provide genius, so we publish nothing, when in fact, repeating ideas is critical to how the internet works. Repetition is vital in oral culture.

If it’s all oral culture online, why does writing matter?

In a word, hypertext.

Online text is searchable. Without text, we have no archives. All record of the conversation is gone when it is not findable. And the way we search video? Text: tags, titles, and descriptions.

Online text is easily linkable and quotable. Aural formats are getting better about clipping and responding to specific pieces of another video or audio snippet, but it’s more natural for text, where hypertext allows a powerful density of information, as Jason Kottke puts it. If I want, I can link every word in a sentence to a different piece of evidence and allow the reader to follow links at their own discretion, backing up and expanding my argument without adding length. Video and audio are limited in what they can reference directly because each added recording requires more time. (I’m not counting the YouTube thing where they add a link overlaid on the video, which is so annoying and disruptive it can’t be used often.)

Online text is accessible, so more people can be included in the conversation. Audio and video are not accessible to Deaf viewers without captions or a transcript… text. Because it’s so much work to transcribe a podcast or video, most are automatically generated and less trustworthy / accurate. Meanwhile, blind readers can use text-to-speech tools to access text. Tools for translating text are more readily available than for translating spoken language (I believe — I’m not really in this space ????‍♀️).

And with text, we are in control of our experience in a way that is harder to achieve with aural media. Text is scannable, so I can quickly skim at a high level to determine if a piece addresses my interest. I can search the text for specific words and jump straight to the content I want; chapter markers in videos help, but are used inconsistently. I can pull out quotes more easily compared with listening to a podcast or video — I can copy and paste from text instead of transcribing by hand. I can change the size of the type and often the color scheme to suit my environment; while you can speed up something aural, it’s disruptive to the work since timing is often an important part of the delivery.

5 blog posts that changed my thinking

It’s rare for a single piece of online writing, on its own, to stand out the same way a traditionally published essay might, because it is part of a larger whole. Blogs influence by vibes moreso than specific, individual posts. Like the drip of water along a stalactite, it’s the accumulation of many posts — sometimes by one author, sometimes by multiple — that changes your mind.

And then sometimes, sometimes, there is that one perfect tweet or provoking blog post.

As a follow-up to collecting my most impactful books, I wanted to celebrate five specific blog posts that were impactful to me. These specific self-published online works gave me concepts that I still value today, or that served as turning points in my thinking.

(NB: I did not necessarily encounter these posts when they first were published.)
  1. No yes. Either HELL YEAH! or no. by Derek Sivers – 2009
    • Helping me turn down projects and save my energy for the things I really care about? Hell yeah! But seriously, actually choosing priorities and recognizing that our human limitations mean we don’t have time for it all is important. This approach also encouraged me to put greater stock in my emotional reaction to projects than obeying what I “should” do.
  2. How I Went From Writing 2,000 Words a Day to 10,000 Words a Day by Rachel Aaron – 2011
    • This post (and the book it inspired) shifted the way I approach writing. I never got to 10k words a day, but this led me to recognize patterns in how, where, and when I write best. Also, using a bullet point / beat level outline made drafting so much easier!
  3. The Shockingly Simple Math Behind Early Retirement by Pete Adeney – 2012
    • I’d been reading personal finance blogs before this — mostly Get Rich Slowly iirc — but this post galvanized me into pursuing financial independence. While we’re more on the Coast FIRE train at this point, developing financial discipline early in my career helped me save enough to have FU money so I could quit my toxic job, and now work part-time.
  4. Don’t Make a Thing Out of It by David Cain – 2014
    • I *totally* used to make a thing out of it. This helped me see that I was doing that — and (mostly) stop.
  5. How to Be a Good Stranger by David Cain – 2014
    • I apply this “secret ally” philosophy to driving, especially, which I think has helped me become a mellower driver.

Most online writing would not meet the bar for traditional publication — but that doesn’t mean it isn’t valuable, or worth preserving. I still appreciate that these bloggers took the time to post their thoughts online where I could find them!

This post is my entry for the November 2024 IndieWeb Carnival, hosted by Alexandra on the theme of impact.

Further reading:

Hypertext, the Memex, and Collaboration as Socialization by Reilly Spitzfaden

A place to talk by Mandy Brown

Standalone but interconnected by Paul Watson

How to converse online by Manu Moreale

A blog post is a very long and complex search query to find fascinating people and make them route interesting stuff to your inbox by Henrik Karlsson

Lost in the Future by Ed Zitron

It’s rare for a single piece of online writing, on its own, to stand out the same way a traditionally published essay might, because it is part of a larger whole. Blogs influence by vibes moreso than specific, individual posts. Like the drip of water along a stalactite, it’s the accumulation of many posts — sometimes by one author, sometimes by multiple — that changes your mind.
And then sometimes, sometimes, there is that one perfect tweet or provoking blog post.
As a follow-up to collecting my most impactful books, I wanted to celebrate five specific blog posts that were impactful to me. These specific self-published online works gave me concepts that I still value today, or that served as turning points in my thinking.
(NB: I did not necessarily encounter these posts when they first were published.)No yes. Either HELL YEAH! or no. by Derek Sivers – 2009
Helping me turn down projects and save my energy for the things I really care about? Hell yeah! But seriously, actually choosing priorities and recognizing that our human limitations mean we don’t have time for it all is important. This approach also encouraged me to put greater stock in my emotional reaction to projects than obeying what I “should” do.

How I Went From Writing 2,000 Words a Day to 10,000 Words a Day by Rachel Aaron – 2011
This post (and the book it inspired) shifted the way I approach writing. I never got to 10k words a day, but this led me to recognize patterns in how, where, and when I write best. Also, using a bullet point / beat level outline made drafting so much easier!

The Shockingly Simple Math Behind Early Retirement by Pete Adeney – 2012
I’d been reading personal finance blogs before this — mostly Get Rich Slowly iirc — but this post galvanized me into pursuing financial independence. While we’re more on the Coast FIRE train at this point, developing financial discipline early in my career helped me save enough to have FU money so I could quit my toxic job, and now work part-time.

Don’t Make a Thing Out of It by David Cain – 2014
I *totally* used to make a thing out of it. This helped me see that I was doing that — and (mostly) stop.

How to Be a Good Stranger by David Cain – 2014
I apply this “secret ally” philosophy to driving, especially, which I think has helped me become a mellower driver.

Most online writing would not meet the bar for traditional publication — but that doesn’t mean it isn’t valuable, or worth preserving. I still appreciate that these bloggers took the time to post their thoughts online where I could find them!
 
This post is my entry for the November 2024 IndieWeb Carnival, hosted by Alexandra on the theme of impact.
 
Further reading:
Hypertext, the Memex, and Collaboration as Socialization by Reilly Spitzfaden
A place to talk by Mandy Brown
Standalone but interconnected by Paul Watson
How to converse online by Manu Moreale
A blog post is a very long and complex search query to find fascinating people and make them route interesting stuff to your inbox by Henrik Karlsson
Lost in the Future by Ed Zitron

summary.value:
Thanks Reilly! No, I think that’s a good point, that I didn’t get into here. I think that is the biggest danger of trying to do something with groups of people with different perspectives, that if you don’t say why you care they might think you’re taking advantage of them, that you think they’re some gullible rube to be used. So I agree it’s important to be open about where we’re coming from if we try to form a coalition with people, or in environmental work be clear who’s organizing and not form some fake cover group. So it’s not just us who would need to be open to “strange allies,” but the other side too — still I think the Left can work on demonstrating their willingness to work together on things, even if building that trust takes a while.
You’ve got a point about the word ‘socialist,’ which has become a bogeyman that’s used to dismiss so many things people would agree with if they could actually hear. I’m thinking about what I’ve been reading about taste, and how important having a framing is for how we feel about things (apparently we like things like modern art better if we can understand what they are / where they fit) — and how much of a role framing serves in politics. I don’t know what to do with that, but the meaning of words matters, and the way conservatives use socialism as a synonym for “un-American” is beyond aggravating.
